Content: Rice: Last week was, I think, the Kickstarter update went out.
So that went over really well and there's a lot of comments about how we all looked really sad in that episode.
Schafer: Cheer up, you guys!
Petty: There were a couple random cuts of me going; that had nothing to do with what was being said.
Rice: It just meant that a lot of people came out of the woodwork that were like, don't be sad, we love the game.
And don't listen to the haters.
Kipnis: Wait, wait. Can you send this link to us?
Rice: Yeah. If you looked at forum threads, the main forum threads.
Schafer: What did you do last week?
Fish: Face it, baby. You're hooked on me.
It's even funnier in the game, you guys.
Rice: Spoiler. Schafer: Spoilers.
[Music] Schafer: I really am trying everything to make sure the game comes out this year.
Rice: It's just going in knowing that that would mean like doing whatever it takes to make that happen.
And sacrificing in some ways.
Schafer: I think we can do December.
To me, it's like an infinity far away.
Schafer: There's like backer expectations.
There is a financial.
And for me, just the possibility of actually being up for awards.
It's really just the best game that we can make and we feel like we can actually make without crashing the company into the ground.
Rice: And so I guess on the screen right now is the current timeline for production on Act Two.
This is what we're working towards and this was the attempt to get to a December launch.
So like even this is stuff that is a real challenge and a lot of people feel, on the team, it's going to take everything, everyone firing like on all cylinders.
Everything falling into the right places.
But seems doable with a push.
And so that is the other challenge, is that all of this requires like our team coming back and working in full, having writing ready to go.
Schafer: On Broken Age? OK, Broken Age.
We have people coming back.
Ray's coming back. Crook: Tomorrow.
Schafer: You're typing something.
You're on Facebook over there.
Crook: Just with my eyes.
Schafer: Facebooking.
Ray's coming back tomorrow.
And Rusty's been back.
Anna's been wiring up actual puzzles in Act Two, right?
Crook: Here we go.
Offscreen Voice: Been a while?
Crook: Deja vu. That's good.
It's good to be back on, back in the world of Shay and Vella.
So I took, took a little time off away from it, not off Double Fine, but just away from the Broken Age and helped out on a couple of other projects.
And that was great, because it was just totally different and just a new, it was a nice break.
Schafer: Wow, the team is big again.
Look at that.
And Oliver's working.
Franzke: We're implementing puzzles and scenes are getting drawn and like sample scripts are getting written, so it's, it's pretty good.
We got Ben back now as well on the project, which is good, exactly.
Peck: Wow. That was a roller coaster, like now we're going to have to do the whole thing over again in less time.
Kipnis: Yeah, I guess at this point it's one of these things where we know that we'll be able to do the game.
The matter will be to the standard that we have in Act One, like that's not a risk however.
That's not a concern that we have.
But we just like, now it's like OK, can we do this in a few months?
And we'll see.
Hansen: Yeah, we worked through a lot of the kinks that we experienced during the Act One, so it's really just about pure execution at this point.
Petty: This wouldn't stay here, but if you had like everything on, so they kind of don't overlap each other
but they all add up versus like this stuff.
Schafer: Cool. That's neat.
Petty: Since it's the only thing that's really changed, hopefully it becomes like the player knows it's a focal point, you know.
They know they need to keep going back, 'cause it's different.
Peck: I'm pretty excited about how much of the tech we already have in place and we can just like hit the ground running on
just writing up the game play and stuff like that.
Crook: So that maybe makes it a little less exciting, in a way, just because it's not new.
As far as figuring things out, but it also makes you less nervous, you know, 'cause we know, OK, it worked.
And you know, there's a few things we want to change.
Crook: We really need to work on the flip book interface.
It's not very intuitive.
Another thing.
Is there any way, Oliver, I know we've mentioned this in the past, but faster exporting of anims from Maya? Yeah.
It's just, you know, it's just these, this, we have a lot of big scenes.
Tim writes long scenes and they, and you make one change, you test it like, ahh, OK, that's good.
Then you got to re-export again, that's another ten, fifteen minutes.
Franzke: I mean, one thing I'm interested to investigate is whether we could launch Maya in batch mode somehow
and like execute a script on it.
Petty: I would if we have a network machine that does it.
Just like when, you know, in Brutal Legend we eventually stopped doing local exports of the movie
and started having the build machine to do it, yeah.
It would also help if we didn't have, you know, seven year old machines with only 4 gigs of RAM.
So it could be fixed by, you know, I don't know.
Crook: Greg. Buy all new computers.
Crook: So it'll, it'll just make workflow easier.
I think it'll save us a lot of time in bug fixing.
Petty: You know, I noticed that there are a lot of animation bugs as the production went on.
And some of those, a lot of those boil down to like sorting issues.
Crook: Basically one piece of geometry didn't know whether it should sort in front or in back of another piece of geometry.
Petty: The way we've done sorting to support all the platforms is limited and they spend a lot of time cleaning that up.
Like if we knew that we were only making it for a high-end console ever, we'd probably have had different solutions
that would have removed some of the burden off the animators or artists, but you know, when you're developing a new engine and you're supporting
a really wide array of platforms, you can't really do that.
Or at least it's harder.
Franzke: Yeah, gosh.
Petty: What do you think, Oliver?
This is way more fun that fixing compatibility errors.
Rice: Yep. So I mean, Ben, you're on some stuff now and I guess a lot of this would be coming your way.
Franzke: How do you feel about crunching?
Petty: I mean it's always a balance for every engine I've been on, 'cause all the games I've worked on I've never used commercial licensed engines.
They've always been developed in-house.
So there's always this balance between getting the game done and adding tools to make making the game more effective.
And it's really hard to know where that balance should be.
Petty: I guess I just wanted to mention that there's a ball of work potentially to like fix some of the workflows that got broken
and also improve some things that I never got a chance to improve, to try and also make the content production of Act Two as efficient as possible.
Franzke: Like, this, this, this schedule to some degree also relies in effect just like in Act One
we actually have some manpower available to fix and even possibly improve the workflow, which is right now really bad,
because it just bi-rotted all alway because nobody had time to really look at it.
Like opening scenes takes insane amount of time, nobody really knows why.
I don't have time to look into it.
Nobody has, Anna needs to work.
We only have two programmers.
Rice: If we're worried about December, that seems like that's going to be something that makes it even more challenging.
Petty: Just something to throw in the bucket with the rest of it.
Petty: And so we're, we're going to a more traditional production cycle now, trying to actually build the very specific game assets,
not just design them, you know.
Preproduction way.
And we're finishing our first sprint of Act Two.
[Music] Schafer: This is the first time we've played through since we started Act Two.
Kipnis: Although I need to make sure that the sound is actually working.
Last time on Broken Age.
Schafer: Are we going to have that?
Oh my God. OK. Here we go.
This better not fucking end here!
It better not be the end!
I paid $15 for, what?
Pull on, OK.
Ohmygod is it going to go right into it? Awesome.
That's so nice and smooth.
So when you play through the game, the only thing is like, do you think we should still put the text up, like "end of Act One"?
Kipnis: No, no, no. It should just go right in.
Schafer: You guys seem to have already come to an agreement about this one.
Kipnis: I mean we could, but it wouldn't be as...
Schafer: Should I pick the girl?
Kipnis: No. Don't do it.
Petty: It'd be a very short play through.
Schafer: It's like, oh no! Horrible bug.
Kipnis: He needs a runs.
Petty: You know what I realized, too, is Shay's in all these scenes.
He feels a bit small in all of them.
He's the correct scale, but he's actually, he's so much smaller feeling than Vella.
Their height is about the same, but because she has the bigger hair and a wider face.
Like he looks small talking to the same characters as if you, like when you just, and I've doubled, triple checked the scale and it's all correct.
It just, Kipnis: I wonder if we should make him bigger.
Petty: Well, it'd throw off all the stuff at this point.
Schafer: So I assume, I think Lydia is awkward.
She came 'cause I think she thinks this is like, yeah, a surprise going away party.
She's coming, is this where, is this where the cake is, you guys?
Is this where we're having the big going away?
This is Lydia's last play-through before she goes to...
That's Oculus. That's my gesture for Oculus.
Facehugger.
Anyone have any last words for Lydia?
Petty: Thank you for all your hard work, Lydia.
[Applause] Kipnis: All your v-effects in Act One were amazing
and we hope we get somebody anywhere near as good as you for Act Two.
Crook: Yeah. Yeah, that was unfortunate.
Good old Lydia.
The turnover here is very, is not high.
It's actually, it's not high at all.
And I think sometimes we're lucky to have people for as long as we do.
And it is a little scary, like we were talking about effects today, a little bit.
Then I was, you know, and then in the back of your head, like wait.
Who's going to do these?
I know Lee was doing a little bit of effects work the other day, but he's not going to have time to like, be the effects person.
So I'm just going to have to trust that they can find somebody.
'Cause we do have, we have a couple other effects artists, but they're on other projects.
So we're going to have to find somebody new that can come in and try and match that style and we will, we will.
And so, so we'll find somebody that can do it.
So I'm not freaking out, but I don't know.
She was great.
Schafer: OK. But it's awesome.
See those puzzles coming together. Kipnis: Yeah.
Schafer: We'll be done by December!
Rice: Exactly. Petty: It's nice that you know when...
Schafer: This is where everyone jumps out and is like, yeah!
Schafer: People were worried about it being done in December, earlier and then the writing is taking even a little bit longer than we thought.
So I bet people were even more worried about it being done in December.
Schafer: But we did not quite finish the work, the milestone and when we started the milestone
we're like, from now on if we don't finish milestones we're just going to cut stuff and when we don't finish them.
And the milestone, so I guess we're just going to have to cut half of those puzzles.
So we're going to go back to that meeting we had where we said that we're going to cut stuff and be like, OK, listen.
It's not totally reasonable to just cut stuff that doesn't get done.
We're going to just have to make up for it somehow.
Petty: The intent was never to be, oh, we didn't finish that puzzle.
We're just not doing it.
It was, it was that we didn't want to leave a wake of unfinished, half-implemented puzzles for a variety of reasons
and one was you can't play-test a half-implemented puzzle meaningfully.
And we wanted to play-test sooner to help ameliorate the amount of like play-tested adjustments at the end
when we have less flexibility, 'cause the dialogue's recorded and we're running out of time.
So I mean, it's all those reasons why we're trying to do that.
But what actually wound up happening for a couple reasons was that we didn't hit those two puzzles.
So we're effectively, I don't know, a week or so behind already on the schedule in our first two-week sprint.
And it's going to continue, like we'll continue to get further behind unless we can close out puzzles on that sprint.
And I don't see anything that changes that.
Right now, for example, there's really only one puzzle that's finished writing.
We can't finish the hull patch puzzle chain, because it's missing writing.
We can't finish the hexapal wiring, we can't finish radiation suit.
So that still means we're behind.
Schafer: ok.
Hansen: Would that allow us to potentially catch up, if we got the writing in time?
Schafer: So I bet I'm maybe the last person who thinks we can get it done in December, probably.
You can kind of sense when you're in a position where everyone kind of thinks you're not going to make the deadline, but they just haven't told you yet.
So I'm going to go ahead and pretend I haven't heard it yet until they, it's just too much time has gone by, they can't tell me.
Then they won't tell me.
And then we'll make it on time, see?
That's how I operate.
Kind of mind games.
Hansen: There're two different scenarios that we can do pretty much.
Well, one is we don't ship in December.
I mean, that's probably the one we don't want to go for.
And the other one, basically eats into Beta periods so that we won't have a true Beta.
We would actually have animations and v-effects and a lot of the audio stuff coming in late, like into Beta.
And there's a lot of risk involved in doing that.
So that was something that we were trying to avoid.
Rice: Then it's like getting the writing done so we can have a VO session in time to where we get the files back soon enough to get our animators
pumping through that from Super Genius, but also so it's not late,
too late to where we're screwing audio and the effects guys.
So there's just kind of a balance in there.
Hansen: We presented Tim with a really aggressive schedule for delivering the writing that we needed in order to keep the team on schedule.
And it was requiring him to work at a faster pace than he's ever written on the projects up to this point.
It's a challenge for everybody, but it all starts with the writings.
Annable: So Tim, did you see the email that I sent you where I said I just did this little exercise.
Schafer: Yeah, I deleted that one immediately.
It was terrifying.
That was the one where you were like...
it looks he spent a year writing this first one, so...
Annable: No, no. And it's, no. 'Cause you didn't take a year; you spent like 13 weeks and to me, you know, we don't,
we don't really succeed when we say hey, Tim, write faster.
It's kind of an impossible thing to do.
So for me, I just don't see December as a, as a reality.
Rice: So I don't know if we want to make a call now or if we want to say let's try to write the rest of the game
in four and a half weeks and still squeeze it in.
Annable: I just worry about the quality then.
I mean, because even if he, Tim, even if you locked yourself away and wrote for a month, you know, I mean that's a lot of pressure.
Schafer: Mmhmm.
Annable: I mean, Tim, do you think you can do that?
Schafer: Again I don't see a lot of choice.
Annable: I mean, it'll be a gnarly schedule for everybody.
Hansen: All right. So why don't we create those scenarios and then we can share the, once this group, and we can talk about it from there.
Schafer: Well, I better get writing. Rice: Yeah.
Annable: All right. Whoohoo! You can do it, Tim. You can do it.
Schafer: OK. Annable: OK.
Schafer: All right. Thanks for talking.
I wish I had more easy solutions for everybody.
Annable: Bye, guys. Schafer: Bye.
Rice: Hi, Malena. OK.
I'm getting Bagel, too.
We'll see if he comes.
Tim is not coming today, you guys.
Kipnis: Why not?
Rice: He is in his office with a big sticker that says "Do Not Disturb".
Melena says.
So he's writing.
No, he's actually, he's been killing it.
He's been cranking through stuff really quick.
I think he sees the deadlines looming and is staying really on top of stuff.
So I think if he keeps going at this pace, then yeah, we're going to have a good shot at it.
Yeah, he's doing his best and it's coming in really nice.
It's solid now, so it's good to see.
Schafer: As long as we can survive 'til the end of the project, it'll be great.
I guess I gotta finish my dialog before...
You guys get to talk to me ever again.
Schafer: Out. Out!
Just kidding.
Come in any time you want to.
Is that a good enough ending?
I'll do like this.
I guess it's just another day in games.
Schafer: Right, right?
I can close my door and I can put a Post-it note on it and I can even lock it.
But just walking around the office, people will be like, ah, I need you to talk, I need to talk to you about this thing.
And then that thing spins into another thing.
And someone wants to talk about another thing.
So many projects going on, so many deals that I probably should be helping with and you know, they justifiably need some input or something.
But I just have to get this writing done.
I just have to get this writing done.
So everything else in the company's got to, got to operate on its own for a little while.
Schafer: We're here at the Noe Valley Public Library.
My house is a few blocks down that way.
I've come to libraries ever since trying to design Full Throttle.
I remember going down to the Sausalito Library and sitting there and designing.
Sitting there with my notebook, same exact thing.
And Grim I went to the library a lot.
I actually did a lot of research in the library, just 'cause the Internet was not full of stuff as it is now.
It's also nice to get out of the office.
It's a change of scenery.
I used to think like, on Full Throttle, I went to the library and I got so much done on the first day.
I was like, this is great, this is my new secret.
And then I went down the next day and I didn't get any work done.
It was like, what's going on?
And I got a lot of work done in the office.
And then sometimes I get a lot of work done in my home.
And sometimes I think there's no one answer.
You just have to keep moving around and shuffling around.
And I think in the end it really in some ways doesn't matter.
You just have to like work at it every day and some days you get nothing done, some days you get a lot done.
But you have to do it every day.
[Music] Schafer: Yeah, it's coming along really fast.
I mean, they really are working twice as fast as Act One.
And we don't have everyone that we had in Act One.
Remember in Act One we had like JP and Brandon, all these people.
This one's been on the gameplay side just like Anna and Ben cranking away on it.
[Music] Rice: There's certain puzzles we should make sure to hit first.
Petty: I think we should hit the stuff that we played the least first, which is the radiation suit puzzle.
I would do that one first. Rice: Cool.
Schafer: Sprint kickoff.
I missed the play-through but I heard it was good.
Rice: The play-through was awesome.
Did anybody have anything they wanted to say about it?
Schafer: It was particularly awesome because I wasn't here.
Like everyone's like, it seems so relaxed.
Petty: That was like a plus.
Schafer: Why is it so chill here?
I don't know what's going on.
Petty: I mean, I think it was pretty solid.
I mean, the puzzles were, they became clear in the play-through that the puzzles were a lot more complex than the first act, which was cool.
Game Tester: This is a good puzzle.
I have no idea what's going on.
It's going to be hard.
You need a pen there, Ben?
Peck: Yeah, I got one.
Petty: Because there are more steps in them and the puzzles, a lot of them aren't just say using an object in a place,
but there's some trial and error things you can manipulate and see different results.
I think the separate puzzle chains kind of weave in and out of each other.
So I think that, that's where some of the, I think some people would describe that as difficulty,
which is true but I think it's also just the appearance.
And, and actual complexity that was maybe missing from some of the puzzles in the first act.
And part of that was by design, both to ramp it up.
But also, you know, Tim, I think in both cases from a story standpoint or from a theme standpoint,
the character's kind of start constrained and therefore the player's kind of constrained.
And they kind of break out of that constraint.
And that means that it was just a little more, there wasn't much opportunity for the puzzles to kind of weave back and forth through each other.
Kipnis: So what are your thoughts, you guys?
Rice: It's fucking awesome. So good.
Kipnis: It's really long. Peck: Yeah.
Rice: It's super fun.
Peck: I really love that last puzzle. Rice: Yeah.
I think it's just like for my level it feels like what we're hoping, which is like much less linear and spread out
and you're having to really kind of retrace your steps a lot.
Petty: So I just realized a flaw, though, right.
Like if you are playing the girl and you take her all the way to the end of her chain, and you haven't seen the [spoiler-bleep]
'cause they're not part of, we have to make sure they're part of her critical puzzle that you have to see them.
Because I'm thinking about this now.
You finished him and you didn't hear [spoiler-bleep], which is what she will need to solve the [spoiler-bleep]
because it's not critical path.
And there's no way to go back to it, 'cause you're in a scrolling thing.
Rice: And yeah, same with him, same with her where if you've gone all the way through and saw it
and just didn't notice it and then now you don't remember the pattern.
Petty: Well, and this one is specifically, you have to be able to go and test it.
And once we put you in this mode, you can never go back.
Peck: Yeah. Petty: So I'm not sure how we solve that.
Rice: That's a good question for Tim.
Schafer: Oh, this is, I feel like this might be a horrible thing I don't want to think about.
Petty: Yeah, we're not really sure what to do about this.
Schafer: It's just, you have that, it works in play-test.
Petty: No! Rice: It doesn't work.
Schafer: Now we've made it so that you, Vella and Shay need each other, like you need things from both areas to work in the other areas.
And we did that on purpose, but then we forget, well, we didn't forget.
We just failed to remember that you can play one character completely and then like in the first act,
you could play all of Shay and then go play all of Vella or vice versa.
And since we made them interdependent, we thought that wasn't a problem.
But if you shut down this whole character and go into that looping animation that means their act is done,
you can't find the things you need to solve this one.
So we're just going to leave that in the unfixable state.
People will be just be like, how far did you get in Broken Age before you couldn't play anymore?
And there'll be like a leader board.
More challenge.
No more hand holding.
I just haven't figured out a solution to that yet.
It's not going to be pretty.
Schafer: Instead of going into the end state where looping, if you haven't solved one of those puzzles, they go into these other states.
Basically stalling.
Rice: At that point it does feel like it's kind of closing people off and a bit handhold-y.
I don't know. Yeah.
Schafer: OK, So we acknowledge that that is a horrible problem for Ben to solve.
Petty: That we're trying to introduce some, more than just story relationships between the separate characters.
And since we've only really taken Shay's second act to Alpha, the exact solution for how to kind of play on those
and that gameplay impact isn't really obvious until we develop more of Vella's side of things.
Rice: I'm really happy with Alpha on the section we just did.
And I don't know, the rest of development is super tight if we're still trying to get December.
And I think that everybody really wants to make it happen so I think that if we can keep pushing forward it should be,
at least we got a shot right now.
I think a lot of it's going to come down to like this next month and a half is really important.
In three, four weeks we'll see where the writing is and hopefully if things look good
we can rally behind it and push to make it happen.
Crook: I don't know. December.
What are we in, October?
November, yeah, no.
That's not going to happen.
As far as I can tell.
But we do not, I have not heard another date.
That's the only date I've heard, but I just think that there's, there's too much work, I think.
As far as I can tell, there's way too much work, but that's kind of up to the producers to figure that out.
[Music] Schafer: The puzzles are great, the writing is late.
But I've been getting some more done, so everybody shut up.
Rice: Like we're just not moving at the pace that that timeline has us moving at.
And now that we're getting more and more writing, we're having a better idea of what it's looking like, too.
But yeah, I think that the conversation of December is still conversation that's happening and one that needs to probably be had further, soon.
'Cause this is another sprint of like pushing stuff off into the next sprint as we have been.
Kipnis: The problem with Vella's side is that there are a lot of like mechanical or physical puzzles
that are like, I don't know if it's going to communicate what we want.
Like I don't know if it's going to work exactly like how we expect.
I just, I worry about the deadline.
Rice: I think it's true, I just don't know if it's going to be able to, if it's going to be able to affect the timing or the VO sessions and stuff.
'Cause otherwise we're pushing it off to where Camden seemed to get dropped with a bunch of stuff and...
Petty: That sounds like the perfect solution to me.
Rice: Well, and Ray and the animators are just, yeah, going to be looking for stuff.
Crook: Effects artist...
Schafer: Push him a little farther until he gets grumpy..
Petty: Oh the effects artist we're going to hire.
Schafer: Still trying to make December.
I mean a lot of it's hard for people to commit to something being done on a certain date if a lot of things are unknown.
Like we don't know what the final act is going to look like.
And like I can see it, but if they don't know exactly what all the assets are going to be, it's hard for them to say it will be done by December.
But I still feel good about it.
Schafer: I, I think I found it and brought it in and left it as a gift for my producers.
Just to give them something I could never actually give them in real life.
I mean, if we're not done in December, we'd definitely be done in January, that's the thing.
So it just seems like so close, like why miss it.
Schafer: I finally finished the Act Two girl dialogue, so the spaceship dialogue is done,
which is exciting for me personally, thank you, Anna.
Yeah, it's between us.
It's really important.
So now I'm just writing, I just to have to write the finale, which looks like this.
Had a lot of spoilers right there.
Don't film that part.
Schafer: I got to finish.
I'm so close to being done with the dialogue for the game, which would be a huge milestone in my life,
'cause all I can think about is dialogue for this game.
There's a lot of dialogue in this game.
Offscreen Voice: So why are you standing up?
Schafer: I'm standing up 'cause I had my gall bladder out.
I'm trying to act cool so people don't know that I had it out, but I don't like to sit down,
'cause if I fold the part where they cut me open and take it out, it kind of hurts.
But that was on Friday.
And now it's Monday, I'm fine.
It's no big deal, gall bladders are stupid, overrated.
Offscreen Voice: Is that because of the juice diet?
Schafer: No one knows if it was because of the juice diet or not.
Like some people, the doctor said it's just genetic and you're just prone to having gall bladders, gall bladder stones, gallstones.
But my wife is sure it's the juice diet.
Offscreen Voice: So no more juice?
Schafer: I don't know.
This has been a long project.
I've been through many bodily changes through this project.
Stress. It's probably just stress, games gonna kill me.
Oh, my tush is going to hurt.
I'm going to sit. I have to sit down.
That pen's a goner, 'cause I can't go down there and get it.
[Music] Schafer: Last week we went to PAX, that was awesome.
We didn't do a bunch of Broken Age stuff 'cause Broken Age is all stealth, Since we're showing the other games.
Rice: A lot of people asked about it, though.
Schafer: A lot of people asked about it, a lot of people said they loved Part One.
Rice: Exactly. Schafer: And that was nice.
Rice: I actually had a lot of people say don't make it harder.
